title: Pride and Prejudice: Chapter 13
author: Jane Austen
description: The introduction of Mr. Collins, the Bennets' cousin and heir to the Longbourn estate, whose arrival via a pompous letter and awkward physical presence brings a mixture of servility and self-importance to the household.
historical_context: The chapter centers on the legal and social implications of the 'entail,' which dictated that the Bennet estate could only be inherited by a male heir, leaving the five daughters potentially destitute. It also introduces the 'clerical patronage' system, where wealthy landowners like Lady Catherine de Bourgh could appoint clergymen to 'livings' (parish positions), granting them significant social and financial stability.
summary: Mr. Bennet surprises his family with the news of an impending visit from Mr. Collins, the man who will inherit Longbourn. A letter from Collins reveals him to be an oddity—extraordinarily deferential to his patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, and awkwardly focused on 'making amends' to the Bennet girls. Upon his arrival, Collins proves to be a tall, formal, and talkative young man. He immediately begins praising the house and its furniture, though he accidentally offends Mrs. Bennet by assuming her daughters cooked the dinner, necessitating a lengthy and tedious apology.

analysis.key_argument_1: The Epistolary Introduction: Austen introduces Mr. Collins through his writing before his physical arrival. The letter serves as a linguistic blueprint of his character, revealing his peculiar blend of 'servility' (towards Lady Catherine) and 'self-importance' (regarding his own clerical duties).
analysis.key_argument_2: The Entail as a Narrative Engine: The chapter reinforces the 'iniquitous' nature of the entailment. By bringing the beneficiary of this system into the Bennet home, Austen transforms an abstract legal grievance into a physical, social intruder, heightening the domestic stakes.
analysis.key_argument_3: Lady Catherine de Bourgh's Shadow: Although she has not yet appeared, Lady Catherine is established as a formidable social force. Collins's obsession with her rank and 'bounty' suggests a worldview entirely dependent on external validation and hierarchical power.
analysis.key_argument_4: Mr. Bennet’s Amused Detachment: Mr. Bennet views Collins not as a threat, but as a source of intellectual sport. His eagerness to meet an 'oddity' reflects his characteristic habit of seeking entertainment in the absurdities of those around him.
analysis.key_argument_5: Mrs. Bennet's Pragmatic Shift: Mrs. Bennet’s transition from 'railing bitterly' against Collins to receiving him with 'composure' demonstrates her ultimate pragmatism. She recognizes that if he is the heir, he is also a potential husband for one of her daughters, making his presence tolerable.
analysis.key_argument_6: The 'Amends' of a Patronizer: Collins’s desire to 'make every possible amends' for inheriting the estate is deeply patronizing. He views his future inheritance as a debt that can be settled through a calculated social or marital transaction, rather than a genuine empathy for his cousins' plight.
analysis.key_argument_7: The Cookery Blunder: Collins’s assumption that the Bennet daughters prepared the meal is a significant class error. In Regency society, a family of their standing keeping a cook was a marker of status; his suggestion that the daughters were in the kitchen implies a lower social rank, revealing his own lack of true 'good breeding.'
analysis.key_argument_8: The Punctuality of a Pedant: Collins's arrival exactly at four o'clock mirrors his rigid, formal nature. His punctuality is not a sign of respect but of a meticulous adherence to social rules that he performs without truly understanding their spirit.

memorable_quotes.quote: It is from my cousin, Mr. Collins, who, when I am dead, may turn you all out of this house as soon as he pleases.
memorable_quotes.explanation: Mr. Bennet's blunt and characteristically dry way of introducing the man who represents the greatest threat to his family’s future security.

memorable_quotes.quote: Nothing can clear Mr. Collins from the guilt of inheriting Longbourn.
memorable_quotes.explanation: An ironic statement by Mr. Bennet, mocking his wife's irrational tendency to blame the person rather than the legal system of entailment.

memorable_quotes.quote: Having received ordination at Easter, I have been so fortunate as to be distinguished by the patronage of the Right Honourable Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
memorable_quotes.explanation: The core of Collins's identity; his status is entirely derived from his proximity to a noblewoman, highlighting his sycophantic nature.

memorable_quotes.quote: I flatter myself that my present overtures of good-will are highly commendable.
memorable_quotes.explanation: Reveals Collins's immense self-satisfaction; he views his basic social decency as an extraordinary act of virtue.

memorable_quotes.quote: Can he be a sensible man, sir? No, my dear; I think not. I have great hopes of finding him quite the reverse.
memorable_quotes.explanation: An exchange between Elizabeth and her father that establishes Collins as the comic foil of the novel, whose lack of sense provides the catalyst for Mr. Bennet's amusement.

memorable_quotes.quote: There is a mixture of servility and self-importance in his letter which promises well.
memorable_quotes.explanation: Mr. Bennet’s precise diagnostic of Collins's character, identifying the two traits that make him both insufferable and ridiculous.

memorable_quotes.quote: He begged to know to which of his fair cousins the excellence of its cookery was owing.
memorable_quotes.explanation: The ultimate social faux pas for Collins, demonstrating his inability to read the room and his clumsy attempts at 'gallantry'.

image_prompts.prompt_text: Highly detailed Renaissance-style painting of a Regency breakfast table. Mr. Bennet stands holding a folded letter with a mischievous glint in his eye. Mrs. Bennet and her five daughters lean forward in various states of intense curiosity and shock. The lighting is bright and morning-clear, focusing on the dynamic range of family expressions.

Highly detailed Renaissance-style painting in the style of Caravaggio. Mr. Bennet is seated in a dark library chair, illuminated by a single, focused light source as he reads Mr. Collins's letter aloud. The deep shadows (Chiaroscuro) emphasize the weight of the document's content, while Elizabeth stands in the background with a skeptical, half-amused face.

Highly detailed Renaissance-style painting. A tall, heavy-looking young man in clerical black (Mr. Collins) stands in the grand entrance of Longbourn. He is performing an exaggeratedly deep bow. The Bennet family is grouped to receive him, their postures reflecting a mix of formal politeness and hidden distaste. The textures of the black wool and the polished floor are highly rendered.

image_prompts.placement: In-line with the praise of furniture
image_prompts.prompt_text: Highly detailed Renaissance-style painting, reminiscent of a Dutch master. Mr. Collins is shown from behind, leaning forward to inspect a fine mahogany sideboard with a look of calculating admiration. He is surrounded by the 'rich' furniture of the dining room. The lighting focuses on the greedy light in his eye and the sheen of the wood.

Highly detailed Renaissance-style painting in the style of Veronese. A grand dinner scene at Longbourn. Mr. Collins is speaking enthusiastically while gesturing toward his plate. Mrs. Bennet is shown with a face of frozen, 'asperity'-filled shock, and the daughters are exchanging quick, knowing glances. The table is laden with silver and fine porcelain.

Highly detailed Renaissance-style painting. A focused portrait of Mr. Collins with his hands clasped and a desperate, fawning expression on his face. He is caught in a moment of endless apology. The background is a soft Sfumato of the drawing room, capturing the exhaustion of the Bennets who are visible in the soft-focus shadows.

Highly detailed Renaissance-style allegorical painting. A tall figure in a black cloak holds a literal, glowing olive branch toward five young women. The scene is bathed in a golden, divine light, but the 'peace-maker's' shadow is long and slightly distorted, suggesting the underlying tension of his arrival. The composition is grand and theatrical.
